comment._content: Interesting to compare with an earlier (no tram loop) photo by Charles Kerry ... [http://www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/2363508174/] from.ph/28690

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] The balloon loop ceased to be used on 11 June 1923 as it stood in the way of the southern approaches to the 'new' bridge. The water tank, which was also in the way of the approach was relocated on 17 July 1923.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johncowper] Do you know when the loop was built? That might provide an earliest date. I can't see Grotto Point Light (see note), which should show as a white blob, as it does on streetview. Built in 1910-11, the lack of it might drag the photo date even earlier to before 1910. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grotto_Point_Light (one of my favourite places in all of Sydney, but sshh, don't tell anyone!).

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Extract from the late David Keenan's book "The North Sydney Lines", published 1987. " Terminal arrangements were improved by the provision of a balloon loop and dead-end siding in September 1914. However wartime economy measures saw the loop taken out of use in May 1916, and it was November 1919 before it was brought back into regular use."

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Notice too the high tension power pylon on the North Sydney side. There was a similar pylon on the Manly side. The crossing carried electricity to the Northern Beaches ... there is no such pole on the Kerry photograph. Manly-The Spit services commenced on 9 January 1911.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Hmm, that does not correspond with the Grotto Point Light dates - maybe it is just not visible. There seems to be a third double-deck ferry at the south side with a ramp to load trams on to it. I think it is this beast (which looks very top-heavy and unsafe to me!) - nla.gov.au/nla.pic-vn6247554 ("ca.1923") . Does the good book have any information about it? I can find nothing in Trove.

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] See [http://www.flickr.com/photos/21647809@N04/5407401214/in/photolist-9eQkZq-hUhMCC ]– I’ll dig out some more details and post them later

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] The official date for the commissioning of the tramcar ferry was 28 July 1912 but according to Ken McCarty’s book “The Manly Lines” it is more probable that it was available in March of that year when major rolling stock transfers took place between the North Sydney and Manly tramway systems. The total cost of constructing and installing the punt was four thousand pounds (about $160,000 dollars in today’s money).
The punt was constructed on a pontoon hull 75 feet long and four foot three inches in depth. It was capable of carrying two O-class bogie trams but in later years it was restricted to carrying only one. A wooden box shaped trestle some 86 feet long carried the trams. 
When not in use the punt was usually moored some 20 feet out from the southern side.
I have heard that he punt was designed by Dr John Bradfield (of Harbour Bridge fame) but have never seen corroborating evidence to that effect.

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: I am surprised that Vaucluse looks much taller than Middle Head from that angle.
